ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I mostly learned this course through a combination of live virtual lectures and recorded lectures.
Combination of recorded lecture and live virtual lecture.
Pre-recorded lectures

pre-lecture reading responses
problem sets
exams
also has pre-recorded component, almost like flipped classroom
The class was a combination of recorded lectures and in-person lectures/breakout rooms.
This class was taught using a combination of prerecorded lectures, which followed with live virtual lectures over zoom during our scheduled class time
Recorded and live lecture
Live virtual discussion
Also in-person discussion / lecture
Recorded lectures with an in person shortened component during regular class meeting times.
Pre-recorded lectures with virtual discussions about the weekly visualizations.
Prerecorded lectures
There were prerecorded lectures that we watched before class and then had live virtual lectures to work through some of the material from the prerecorded lecture.
Live discussion sections and prerecorded lectures.
live lecture as well
Flipped classroom. Lectures were recorded, and in-class time was spent in discussion.
recorded lecture
There were also live, interactive sessions that students could attend, but they were optional.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to use html, css, and js. I learned how to use D3.js to effectively and easily create various data visualizations. I also learned about the important principles and rules of visualization and vis idioms. I learned to find, extract, and visualize useful data.

Learned about the different ways data can be visualized and how to visualize data using d3.js. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sIlNIVXpIns&ab_channel=Lemon
I learned about data visualization using D3 and JS.

how to think about and approach data vis
developed HTML/CSS, JavaScript, specifically D3 skills
data visualization skills

I learned how to use d3 to make all kinds of data visualizations (line charts, bar graphs, etc...) with some animations. I also learned the process of designing a visualization for someone, from understanding their needs to choosing the right visualization.

I learned how to create visualizations using the d3 library, design visualizations, determine the tasks and data abstractions necessary, and how to make these  visualizations interactive. I also learned about human perception with regards to making more effective visualizations
Javascript html css and visualization theories
I developed insights into data visualization
Learned how to effectively create visualizations to accurately answer the questions being asked. Also got to learn javascript and d3!

I learned about Data Visualization using D3.js and how to effectively visualize data. I learned about the psychology, intuition, and optics of visualization and various components that go into producing a good data vis.
I learned a lot about how to construct and analyze and understand different visual idioms while also becoming more proficient with Coding in javascript and using d3.

I learned how to use javascript and d3 to create visualizations from scratch. I also learned what is effective and what is not effective when it comes to design and algorithm choices for displaying data.
Learned ways to visualize data.
I learned how to write code more efficiently, use d3, and make good visualizations

I learned about the fundamentals ideas behind data visualization, a hodge-podge of related principles outside of the textbook like the Gestalt principles, and a number of sample data vis models. I also learned how to break down visualizations and their effectiveness using the book's framework.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how the course lectures were divided into "prelectures" and "live sessions". The prelectures were helpful in that I was able to learn about course content thoroughly, and live sessions were helpful in practicing and asking questions about the contents.

Strengths: clear expectations, engaging lectures, relevant homework assignments
Weaknesses: too much lecture time with prerecorded lecture on top of actual class meetings

Strengths: I feel like I learned a lot, and I enjoyed having speakers come in to talk about different areas in data visualization as well as emerging technologies.
Weakness: Pre-recorded lectures were super long, and we also had live virtual lectures.

not a lot of guidance for learning js at the beginning. at the end, all the work came out of reading docs. I think it taught concepts well though. goes through a lot of material quite quickly. tests are super dense though.

Strengths: The problem sets were a good way to learn d3, and the live lectures were sometimes pretty interesting, although I didn't learn much from them in the end.
Weaknesses: The midterms and final involved a lot of rote memorization. Testing students' abilities to analyze a visualization or choose the right one for a situation might be better.

This course could have been a lot easier if there was a more recent version of the d3 library reference book available. D3 updated during our first week of class, so our textbook was outdated for some parts of the interface. This made trying to do certain parts of the assignment more difficult than necessary, because we essentially had to look up online for examples using the recent version of d3 (often times this took the bulk of the work). Also I felt the use of live and prerecorded lectures resulted in us spending more time in lecture than we would have in a normal, non covid term

Strengths: psets taught a lot about front end languages and were very fair
Weaknesses: live lectures were not the best use of time, recorded lectures had all the content but live lectures were always the same - getting into breakout rooms and discussing pros and cons of different visualizations. Weren't very useful in my opinion but I understand student participation is important.
One strength was that a portion of lectures was prerecorded and the rest was a live discussion.

This course did a great job in teaching D3.js to students. I feel like I learned a lot about the coding aspects and how they related to the concepts taught in class. It would be helpful to have more in-depth discussions about the material.

The course had very interesting and enjoyable problem sets. However, part way through the semester all of the course content was in the prerecorded lectures and I wish a little more time was spent on the actual content in live sessions
Strengths: Well organized material that built on itself. Weakness: Problem sets seemed a bit disconnected from the timeline of material covered in class.
The problem sets were a strong aspect of the course. But given how long they could take I think that they should be weighted more heavily. The parts should be worth much more than they are.
Maybe re-ordering some material would help. Some topics like marks/channels seemed as if they could be better placed earlier in the course.

Strengths: 

The assignments. While not overly hard, they do force you to create one of a lot of different types of charts and make said visualizations interactive. By the time you're finished (if you've completed all the psets and are happy with the structure of your code), you have a solid code base to go back to to create future visualizations. Also the professors -- they are both amazing people, and worth taking a class with. 

Weaknesses: 

Though this course attempted to adapt to online learning, it honestly didn't do a great job of it. To be clear: I really appreciated the amount of effort and thought both professors put into developing this course. But what ended up happening is that students just didn't watch the prerecorded lectures (or waited until right before the exam to watch them), since there was already a required reading due before class (and that had an associated written response assignment).  We spent the in class time looking at interesting data visualizations and analyzing them, but the professors expected simultaneously too much and too little from the students -- after being put into breakout rooms and discussing for 10 minutes, we'd come back and spend the next half hour recapping what went on in each breakout room. This was too much engagement (it got boring, students didn't speak up, and honestly I think a lot of us were there so our participation grade didn't go down) given the little amount of work we'd done in the breakout rooms.

I wish the course could have included questions that followed up not on just readings, but on the recorded lecture. I think that would have maximized engagement there. 

I really liked in the in-person format - it helped me think more about applications

Strengths - the asynchronous lectures were much better than any live versions. The psets were also very fair.

Weaknesses - I felt very unprepared for some of the questions on the exams, especially the short answers, which felt like "gotcha" questions and were super detailed, rather than testing principles and general understanding.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since both the pre and live lectures were recorded, international students like myself were able to learn at their convenient times. The courses provided reasonable time slots (considering time differences overseas) for oral exams as well.

I think that the prerecorded lecture and live lecture combination format resulted in too much lecture time. I would implore the professors to choose one or the other so that students aren't overburdaned.
was fine. professors did a good job of engaging everyone.

The format of recorded lecture and then live breakout rooms along with a reading assignment before every lecture ended up getting pretty tedious towards the end of the semester. Also, the kinds of things we looked at in live lecture didn't really help cement the knowledge in my mind so much as just asking us to learn how to use some random online tool.
Teach the course content in the live lecture instead.
I think a big success was having a portion of lectures being prerecorded and the rest as a live discussion.
The recorded lectures definitely made it a lot easier to learn on your own time but the in person component ensured that I was not falling behind.
This class was taught very well online. It would be fun to do a group project or find a way to interact with the other classmates more.
The exams were well executed, I think lecture grew a bit dry later on as the semester went on
I think having questions to answer and submit before each class helped maintain the engagement as did the smaller breakout groups during live lecture.
I think this course did a good job overall, the best it could given the circumstances. I think the format of the exams could have been improved.
see the 'weaknesses' section of question #4
the use of breakout rooms and recorded lecs worked.

Success - asynchronous lectures. Also, I appreciated that the live sessions were optional. 

Weaknesses - the content was sometimes a little dry in the recorded lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, because I got to practice coding in HTML, CSS, and JS a lot throughout the course. I also learned how to create cool visualizations using D3.js.
If you're interested in data visualization, this is a good computer science course to take.

I would definitely recommend this course to CS majors looking to fulfill one of their electives. It has been one of my favorite CS classes that I've taken at Yale, being both lower in workload yet still super interesting.

The material is covered is really interesting and the psets are fun and develop your D3 skills well.
The exams require a lot of preparation, but you solidify the course material through reviewing for them.
yes. important to learn

I would recommend this course to anyone who is really interested in the creation of visualizations and some of the reasoning behind each vis type. You'll learn d3 throughout the semester, and there are some interesting guest lectures.
I would recommend this course to someone interested in taking a relatively easy and useful CS elective.
Yes. The psets and exams are pretty fair, make sure to keep up with lectures, however, because a lot of the visualization theories are taught from the textbook and aren't related to the psets.
Yes
I would not recommend this class. I thought the lectures were incredibly boring and hard to listen too. The readings were difficult, long and often felt irrelevant.

This is a great course to learn D3.js and Data Visualization! I would recommend it to students who want to learn a new language and also the psychology and intuition behind creating meaningful and effective visualizations.
Yes, if you dont have experience in d3 or javascript and wish to pick up some of these skills
Yes, it is a good introduction to creating visualization and helps you think about the visualizations you see on a daily basis
Depending on what their schedule looks like, yes. Some useful material in the course, but also a lot of fluff.

If you're interested in data visualization, by all means, take this class, but be willing to work to understand the material yourself. And know that you'll be learning a bunch of theory in class, and doing the practical bits (which might interest you the most) in the psets for the class, which are not worth that much of your grade. That said, you'll definitely leave the class with some practical skills, and with a solid overview of the field of data visualization.
Yes, if you want to make websites accompanied with visualizations, this is super useful!

It's a good CS elective to take if you're looking for one and are interested in data vis. Did this course knock it out of the ballpark? Nah. Was it a total miss? Nope. Just overall, not bad, with not an intense workload. You do need to study for the exams though, as there are a couple of gotcha questions, but if you watch the recorded lectures, you should be fine.

extras.title:
CPSC 546 01/CPSC 446 01
        Data and Info Visualization/Data and Info. Visualization
